introduction.p: In the previous section, we used the radius of a circle, r, and an angle, \theta to define polar coordinates. In this section, we use these variables to find the length of arcs on circles.

assemblage.p: An arcarc is a portion of the circumference of a circle.
Arc lengthArc length is defined as the length of an arc, s, along a circle of radius r subtended (drawn out) by an angle \theta.
The length of the arc around an entire circle is called the circumferencecircumference of the circle. The circumference of a circle is C=2\pi r

introduction.p: Recall that we defined radians as an angle measurement that arises by looking at angles as a fraction of the unit circle. Since the radius of the unit circle is 1, the circumference of the unit circle is 2\pi. This is why there are 2\pi radians in one complete trip around a circle. Thus, arc lengths on the unit circle correspond to the angle measures (in radians) that those arcs subtend.

What if the circle has radius r? If the circle is subtended by an angle of \theta radians, then the arc makes up a fraction of \frac{\theta}{2\pi} of the whole circumference. Since the circumference is 2\pi r, we can compute the arc length as follows.

assemblage.title: Arc Length Formula
assemblage.p:
For a circle of radius r subtended by an angle of \theta radians, the length s of the corresponding arc is
s=2\pi r\cdot\frac{\theta}{2\pi}
or simply
s=r\theta
